maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new node to the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Add-NlbClusterNode cmdlet adds a new node to the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. Once the new node settings are circulated through all of the NLB cluster nodes, the new cluster node will be in a running state in the cluster.

This cmdlet changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies the name of the new cluster node.
Specifies the interface name on the new cluster node.
Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet asks for confirmation from the user before proceeding.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the name of the new cluster node.
Specifies the interface name on the new cluster node.
Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet asks for confirmation from the user before proceeding.
Specifies the cluster to which the node is added.
Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet asks for confirmation from the user before proceeding.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster to which the node is added.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the interface name on the new cluster node.
Specifies the name of the new cluster node.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster node1 | Add-NlbClusterNode -NewNodeName node2 -NewNodeInterface vlan-3 Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node2 Converged vlan-3 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds the host named node2 to the cluster on the node named node1.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a dedicated IP address to a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Add-NlbClusterNodeDIP cmdlet adds a dedicated IP address to a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. NLB references the dedicated IP address to handle both client-to-cluster traffic and other network traffic that must go specifically to the cluster node.

This cmdlet changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies the dedicated IP address for the new cluster node.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the subnet mask for the dedicated IP address of the new cluster node.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the dedicated IP address for the new cluster node.
Specifies the subnet mask for the dedicated IP address of the new cluster node.
Specifies the node of the cluster to which the dedicated IP address is added.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the dedicated IP address for the new cluster node.
Specifies the node of the cluster to which the dedicated IP address is added.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the subnet mask for the dedicated IP address of the new cluster node.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode node2 | Add-NlbClusterNodeDip fe80::b3c4:cc5:64dd:6e62 Node IPAddress SubnetMask ---- --------- ---------- node2 fe80::b3c4:cc5:64dd:6e62

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds the specified dedicated IP address to the cluster node named node2.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-NlbClusterNodeDip -HostName node2 -InterfaceName vlan-3 -IP fe80::b3c4:cc5:64dd:6e62 Node IPAddress SubnetMask ---- --------- ---------- node2 fe80::b3c4:cc5:64dd:6e62

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds the specified dedicated IP address to the cluster node named node2 on the interface named vlan-3.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a new port rule to a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Add-NlbClusterPortRule cmdlet adds a new port rule to a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. Port rules control how an NLB cluster functions. To maximize the control of various types of TCP/IP traffic, you can set up port rules to control how each port's cluster-network traffic is handled. The method by which a port's network traffic is handled is called its filtering mode. There are three possible filtering modes: Multiple hosts, Single host, and Disabled. A filtering mode can also apply to a numerical range of ports. You do this by defining a port rule with a set of configuration parameters that define the filtering mode. In addition, you can select one of three options for client affinity: None, Single, or Network. Single and Network are used to ensure that all network traffic from a particular client is directed to the same cluster host. To allow NLB to properly handle IP fragments, you should avoid using None when you select UDP or Both for your protocol setting.

This cmdlet changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies the start port for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the end port for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the type of affinity for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Network, None, or Single.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the IP address for the new cluster port rule.
Specifies the filtering mode for the new cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Disabled, Multiple, and Single.
Specifies the protocol for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Both, TCP, or UDP.
Specifies the timeout in minutes for the new cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 240.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the start port for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the end port for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the type of affinity for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Network, None, or Single.
Specifies the IP address for the new cluster port rule.
Specifies the filtering mode for the new cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Disabled, Multiple, and Single.
Specifies the protocol for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Both, TCP, or UDP.
Specifies the timeout in minutes for the new cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 240.
Specifies the cluster to which the port rule is added.
Specifies the type of affinity for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Network, None, or Single.
Specifies the end port for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the IP address for the new cluster port rule.
Specifies the cluster to which the port rule is added.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the filtering mode for the new cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Disabled, Multiple, and Single.
Specifies the protocol for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Both, TCP, or UDP.
Specifies the start port for the new port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the timeout in minutes for the new cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 240.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster | Add-NlbClusterPortRule -StartPort 443 -EndPort 443 IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 443 443 Both Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds a new port rule to the local cluster. The new port rule covers port 443 only, and uses the default settings for the rest of the port rule parameters.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster | Add-NlbClusterPortRule -StartPort 80 -EndPort 80 -Affinity None IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 80 80 Both Multiple None 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds a new port rule to the local cluster. The new port rule covers port 80 only and has no affinity, and uses the default settings for the rest of the port rule parameters.

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a virtual IP address to a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Add-NlbClusterVIP cmdlet adds a virtual IP address to a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. The virtual IP address will appear on all hosts in the cluster. This IP address is used to address the cluster as a whole, and it should be the IP address that maps to the full Internet name that you specify for the cluster.

This cmdlet changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies the IP address of the new cluster to which the virtual IP address is added.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the subnet mask for the virtual IP address of the new cluster.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the IP address of the new cluster to which the virtual IP address is added.
Specifies the subnet mask for the virtual IP address of the new cluster.
Specifies the cluster to which the cluster virtual IP address is added.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the IP address of the new cluster to which the virtual IP address is added.
Specifies the cluster to which the cluster virtual IP address is added.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the subnet mask for the virtual IP address of the new cluster.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Add-NlbClusterVip -IP fe80::94dc:5e59:3626:f1d4 -InterfaceName vlan-3 IPAddress SubnetMask --------- ---------- fe80::94dc:5e59:3626:f1d4 ::

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds an IPv6 IP address to the list of virtual NLB cluster IP addresses on the network interface vlan-3.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster | Add-NlbClusterVip -IP fe80::94dc:5e59:3626:f1d4 IPAddress SubnetMask --------- ---------- fe80::94dc:5e59:3626:f1d4 ::

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example adds an IPv6 IP address to the list of virtual NLB cluster IP addresses on the local cluster.

maml:description.maml:para: Disables a port rule on a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster or on a specific host in the cluster.

The Disable-NlbClusterPortRule cmdlet disables a specific port rule on a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster or on a specific host in the NLB cluster. Disabling new traffic handling should be considered for the port rule using the optional Drain parameter. Specifying the Drain parameter at the cluster level drains the specified ports on all hosts within the cluster, and specifying it at the host level drains the ports on the specific host only.
Specifies a port number within the port rule that will be disabled. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Disables the given port rule on all cluster nodes. If this parameter is omitted, then the port rule is only disabled on one node.
Drains existing traffic before disabling this port rule. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing traffic will be dropped.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule that will be disabled.
Specifies the number of minutes to wait for the drain operation before the port rule is disabled. After the time expires, the existing connections will be dropped.
Drains existing traffic before disabling this port rule. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing traffic will be dropped.
Specifies the number of minutes to wait for the drain operation before the port rule is disabled. After the time expires, the existing connections will be dropped.
Specifies the cluster port rule to disable.
Disables the given port rule on all cluster nodes. If this parameter is omitted, then the port rule is only disabled on one node.
Drains existing traffic before disabling this port rule. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing traffic will be dropped.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule that will be disabled.
Specifies the cluster port rule to disable.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies a port number within the port rule that will be disabled. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the number of minutes to wait for the drain operation before the port rule is disabled. After the time expires, the existing connections will be dropped.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Disable-NlbClusterPortRule -Port 80 IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Disabled 80 80 Both Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example disables the port rule for port number 80 on the local cluster.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterPortRule | Disable-NlbClusterPortRule IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Disabled 80 80 Both Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example disables all port rules on the local cluster.

maml:description.maml:para: Enables a port rule on a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster or on a specific node in the cluster.
The Enable-NlbClusterPortRule cmdlet enables a specific port rule on a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster or on a specific node in the NLB cluster.
Specifies a port number within the port rule that will be enabled. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Enables the given port rule on all cluster nodes. If this parameter is omitted, then the port rule is only enabled on one node.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule that will be enabled.
Specifies the cluster port rule to enable.
Enables the given port rule on all cluster nodes. If this parameter is omitted, then the port rule is only enabled on one node.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule that will be enabled.
Specifies the cluster port rule to enable.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies a port number within the port rule that will be enabled. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Enable-NlbClusterPortRule -Port 80 IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 80 80 Both Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example enables port rule 80 on the local cluster.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterPortRule | Enable-NlbClusterPortRule IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 80 80 Both Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example enables all port rules on the local cluster.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves information about the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster object that is queried by the caller.
The Get-NlbCluster cmdlet retrieves information about the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. The information includes the properties, or attributes, that define the cluster and its status.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- cluster1 3.53.100.100 255.0.0.0 UNICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets the cluster object for the local NLB cluster, that is, the cluster that this node is a part.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster -HostName node1 Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- cluster2 4.53.100.100 255.0.0.0 UNICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets the cluster object for the NLB cluster that node named node1 is a part.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 3
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster -HostName node1 -InterfaceName vlan-2 Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- cluster2 4.53.100.100 255.0.0.0 UNICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets the cluster object for the NLB cluster that node named node1 (with the interface named vlan-2) is a part.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves information about the Network Load Balancing (NLB) driver on the local machine.

The Get-NlbClusterDriverInfo cmdlet retrieves information about the Network Load Balancing (NLB) driver on the local machine. This includes information about IP addresses, ports, convergence history, connections, extended affinity status, and protocols.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Gets the list information about the NLB driver on this node.
Specifies the connection tuple client port that is used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the type of packet that is used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic. The acceptable values for this parameter are: SYN FIN or RST.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the connection tuple server port used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the connection client IP address that is used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic.

Determines whether or not a certain traffic pattern will be picked by this cluster node. The parameter specifies the protocol that is used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic. The acceptable values for this parameter are: TCP or UDP.
Specifies the connection tuple server IP address used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Gets the history of convergences between the cluster nodes.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Gets the extended affinity exception list on this cluster node.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Gets the extended affinity list on this cluster node.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Gets the list of open connections to the cluster.
Specifies the connection client IP address that is used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic.
Specifies the connection tuple client port that is used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Gets the history of convergences between the cluster nodes.
Gets the extended affinity exception list on this cluster node.
Gets the extended affinity list on this cluster node.

Determines whether or not a certain traffic pattern will be picked by this cluster node. The parameter specifies the protocol that is used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic. The acceptable values for this parameter are: TCP or UDP.
Specifies the type of packet that is used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic. The acceptable values for this parameter are: SYN FIN or RST.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Gets the list of open connections to the cluster.
Gets the list information about the NLB driver on this node.
Specifies the connection tuple server IP address used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic.
Specifies the connection tuple server port used to check whether the current cluster node accepts or drops the traffic. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterDriverInfo FullyQualifiedDomainName : cluster1.contoso.com ParametersVersion : 6 EffectiveNlbVersion : 513 HostId : 2 ClusterName : cluster1 ClusterIPAddress : 2001:4898:e8:3018:bd82:dde1:6615:7b0 ClusterMacAddress : 02-BF-FB-7E-A2-D1 AliveMsgPeriod : 1000 MaxConnectionDescriptors : 262144 IcmpFilteringEnabled : False InitialHostState : Started CurrentHostState : Started PersistedHostStates : True

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets information about the NLB driver configuration.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterDriverInfo -ConvergenceHistory Time FromState ToState ---- --------- ------- 11/5/2008 10:55:27 PM StablePhase2 Converged 11/5/2008 10:55:26 PM ConvergingPhase2 StablePhase2 11/5/2008 10:55:26 PM StablePhase1 ConvergingPhase2 11/5/2008 10:55:20 PM ConvergingPhase1 StablePhase1 11/5/2008 10:55:17 PM Unknown ConvergingPhase1

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets the history of convergence for the local node.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 3
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterDriverInfo -Filter TCP -ServerIP 2.53.4.222 -ServerPort 5001 -ClientIP 2.53.4.5 -ClientPort 5001 Result ------ ACCEPT_UNCONDITIONAL_OWNERSHIP

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example declares whether traffic in the given pattern will be accepted on the local node or not.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 4
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterDriverInfo -ExtendedAffinityList IPAddress References VirtualIPAddress StartPort --------- ---------- ---------------- --------- 2.53.4.5 0 All 0 2.53.4.6 0 All 0 2.53.4.7 1 All 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will enumerate the client IP addresses that are on the extended affinity list on this cluster node. This applies to port rules that have extended affinity timeout enabled. The cmdlet also displays the number of active connections for each client.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 5
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterDriverInfo -ExtendedAffinityExceptionList IPAddress HostId VirtualIPAddress StartPort --------- ------ ---------------- --------- 2.53.4.6 2 All 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example will enumerate the client IP addresses that are on the extended affinity exception list. This applies to port rules that have extended affinity timeout enabled. Traffic from clients on this list will be picked up by another cluster node that has the host ID listed.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 6
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterDriverInfo -OpenConnections SourceIPAddress SourcePort DestinationIPAddres DestinationPorts
--------------- ---------- ------------------- --------------- 2.53.4.5 64945 2.53.4.222 5001 2.53.4.15 64854 2.53.4.222 80

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example enumerates all open connections on this cluster node. This is useful to run when the draining operation takes a long time and the administrator wants to know which connections are on the node.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves information about a node object or the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster object that is queried by the caller.

The Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet retrieves information about a node in the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. The information includes the properties, or attributes, that define the node and its status.
Specifies the cluster node name to retrieve.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the cluster node name to retrieve.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster for which the nodes are enumerated.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster for which the nodes are enumerated.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the cluster node name to retrieve.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node1 Converged(default) vlan-3 1 node2 Converged vlan-3 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example lists nodes that are part of the local cluster. It also shows the state of the nodes and the interface to which NLB is bound on each node.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode -NodeName node1 | Format-List * Cluster : mycluster Name : node1 InterfaceName : vlan-3 Host : State : Converged HostPriority : 2 AdapterGuid : {} InitialHostState : Started PersistSuspendOnReboot : True MaskSourceMac : True FilterIcmp : 0 GreDescriptorTimeout : 10

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets details about cluster node named node1.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the dedicated IP address that is queried by the caller.

The Get-NlbClusterNodeDIP cmdlet retrieves the dedicated IP address that is requested by the caller. This IP address is the unique IP address of the local host that is used for dedicated traffic to the host or network traffic that is not associated with the cluster. Network Load Balancing (NLB) never load balances traffic for the dedicated IP address. Instead, NLB load balances incoming traffic from all IP addresses other than the dedicated IP address.
Specifies the IP address of the cluster node for which the dedicated IP address is retrieved.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the name of the cluster node for which the dedicated IP address is retrieved.
Specifies the IP address of the cluster node for which the dedicated IP address is retrieved.
Specifies the node of the cluster for which the dedicated IP address is retrieved.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the IP address of the cluster node for which the dedicated IP address is retrieved.
Specifies the node of the cluster for which the dedicated IP address is retrieved.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the name of the cluster node for which the dedicated IP address is retrieved.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNodeDip Node IPAddress SubnetMask ---- --------- ---------- node1 3.53.4.1 255.0.0.0 node1 fe80::a9cb:eafb:e841:d8cf node2 3.53.4.2 255.0.0.0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example lists all the dedicated IP addresses on the local cluster node.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2

PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNodeNetworkInterface InterfaceName : vlan-3 NlbBound : True Cluster : cluster1 DhcpEnabled : False InterfaceIP : 3.53.4.1 InterfaceSubnetMask : 255.0.0.0 ClusterPrimaryIP : 3.53.100.100 ClusterSubnetMask : 255.0.0.0
InterfaceName : vlan-2 NlbBound : False Cluster : DhcpEnabled : False InterfaceIP : 2.53.4.1 InterfaceSubnetMask : 255.0.0.0 ClusterPrimaryIP : ClusterSubnetMask :

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves the port rule objects that are queried by the caller.
The Get-NlbClusterPortRule cmdlet retrieves the port rules in the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. If a port number is not specified, all port rules configured for the cluster are listed.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterPortRule IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 0 65535 Both Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example lists all the port rules on the local cluster.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterPortRule -Port 80 IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 0 65535 Both Multiple Single 0

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 3
command:example.dev:code:
PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode | Get-NlbClusterPortRule | Format-List –Property * Cluster : mycluster NodeName : node1 VirtualIPAddress : 255.255.255.255 StartPort : 0 EndPort : 65535 Affinity : FilteringMode : Single Protocol : Both EqualLoad : False LoadWeight : PortState : Enabled Priority : 1 Timeout :
Cluster : mycluster NodeName : node2 VirtualIPAddress : 255.255.255.255 StartPort : 0 EndPort : 65535 Affinity : FilteringMode : Single Protocol : Both EqualLoad : False LoadWeight : PortState : Enabled Priority : 2 Timeout :

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example gets the port rule from all cluster nodes. This is especially useful if there are port rules that have Single mode.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster on the specified interface that is defined by the node and network adapter name.

The New-NlbCluster cmdlet creates a new Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. The following will need to be defined: the node name, the network adapter, primary IP address, dedicated IP address, and the name of the cluster.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the primary cluster IP address for the new cluster.
Specifies the name of the new cluster.
Specifies the dedicated IP address to use for the node when creating the new cluster. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing static IP address on the node will be used.

Specifies the dedicated IP address subnet mask to use for the node when creating the new cluster. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing static IP address subnet mask on the node will be used.

Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet will ask for confirmation from the user before proceeding. This parameter applies if the DHCP setting on the interface needs to be overwritten by the cmdlet.
Specifies the operation mode for the new cluster. If this parameter is omitted, then the mode is UNICAST. The acceptable values for this parameter are: IGMPMULTICAST, MULTICAST, or UNICAST.
Specifies the subnet mask for the new cluster primary IP address.
Specifies the name of the new cluster.

Specifies the dedicated IP address to use for the node when creating the new cluster. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing static IP address on the node will be used.

Specifies the dedicated IP address subnet mask to use for the node when creating the new cluster. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing static IP address subnet mask on the node will be used.

Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet will ask for confirmation from the user before proceeding. This parameter applies if the DHCP setting on the interface needs to be overwritten by the cmdlet.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the operation mode for the new cluster. If this parameter is omitted, then the mode is UNICAST. The acceptable values for this parameter are: IGMPMULTICAST, MULTICAST, or UNICAST.
Specifies the subnet mask for the new cluster primary IP address.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>New-NlbCluster -InterfaceName vlan-3 -ClusterPrimaryIP 3.53.100.100 -ClusterName cluster1 Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- cluster1 3.53.100.100 255.0.0.0 UNICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example creates a one-node NLB cluster on the current machine. The created cluster is named cluster1 and has one virtual IP address 3.53.100.100. This assumes that the interface is not DHCP-enabled.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a node from the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Remove-NlbClusterNode cmdlet removes a node from the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. Once a node is removed, NLB will redistribute the client traffic among the remaining servers in the cluster.

This cmdlet changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet will ask for confirmation from the user before proceeding.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a port rule from a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Remove-NlbClusterPortRule cmdlet removes a port rule from a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. Port rules control how an NLB cluster functions. To maximize the control of various types of TCP/IP traffic, port rules can be set up to control how each port's cluster-network traffic is handled. The number and type of port rules must be exactly the same for each node in the cluster. If a node attempts to join the cluster with a different number of rules or with different rules from the other nodes, then it is not accepted as part of the cluster.

This cmdlet changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies a port number within the port rule to remove. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet will ask for confirmation from the user before proceeding.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.

Sends items from the interactive window down the pipeline as input to other cmdlets. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule to remove.

maml:description.maml:para: Resumes all nodes of a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.
The Resume-NlbCluster cmdlet resumes all nodes in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. To override any remote control commands that are issued, a cluster may need to be suspended and resumed.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the cluster to resume.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster to resume.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Resume-NlbCluster Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- cluster1 3.53.100.100 255.0.0.0 UNICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example resumes all cluster nodes on the local cluster. Cluster nodes are in the Stopped state after this cmdlet runs. Run the Start-NlbCluster cmdlet to start all cluster nodes.

maml:description.maml:para: Resumes a node in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Resume-NlbClusterNode cmdlet resumes the node in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster that was suspended. To override any remote control cmdlets that are issued, a node may need to be suspended and resumed.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Resume-NlbClusterNode Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node2 Stopped vlan-3 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example resumes the local cluster node. The node is in the Stopped state and needs to be started after coming back from the Suspended state.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Resume-NlbClusterNode -InputObject node3 Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node3 Stopped vlan-3 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example resumes the cluster node named node3 on the local cluster. The node is in the Stopped state and needs to be started after coming back from the Suspended state.

maml:description.maml:para: Edits the configuration of a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Set-NlbCluster cmdlet edits the configuration of a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. The configuration changes you can make include the cluster operation mode (MULITCAST or UNICAST), the cluster name, and the cluster primary IP address.

This operation changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the IP address to use as the cluster primary IP address. The IP address must be one of the existing virtual IP addresses on the cluster.
Specifies the new name of the cluster.
Specifies the new operation mode for the cluster. The acceptable values for this parameter are: IGMPMULTICAST, MULTICAST, or UNICAST.
Specifies the IP address to use as the cluster primary IP address. The IP address must be one of the existing virtual IP addresses on the cluster.
Specifies the new name of the cluster.
Specifies the new operation mode for the cluster. The acceptable values for this parameter are: IGMPMULTICAST, MULTICAST, or UNICAST.
Specifies the cluster to set.
Specifies the IP address to use as the cluster primary IP address. The IP address must be one of the existing virtual IP addresses on the cluster.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster to set.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the new name of the cluster.
Specifies the new operation mode for the cluster. The acceptable values for this parameter are: IGMPMULTICAST, MULTICAST, or UNICAST.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster | Set-NlbCluster -Name newcluster Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- newcluster fe80::b349:6945:... :: UNICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the cluster name to newcluster.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster | Set-NlbCluster -OperationMode MULTICAST Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- newcluster fe80::b349:6945:... :: MULTICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the cluster operation mode to MULTICAST.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 3
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbCluster | Set-NlbCluster -ClusterPrimaryIP 2.53.0.120 Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- newcluster 2.53.0.120 255.0.0.0 MULTICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the cluster primary IP address to one of the other cluster virtual IP addresses on the cluster.

maml:description.maml:para: Edits the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster node settings.

The Set-NlbClusterNode cmdlet edits the Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster node settings. The changes you can make include reconfiguring the host priority, the initial host state, and whether to persist suspended states across reboots.

This operation changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet will ask for confirmation from the user before proceeding.
Specifies the host priority or host ID for the cluster node. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 1 through 32.
Specifies the initial host state for the cluster node. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Started, Stopped, or Suspended.
Causes the NLB driver on the current cluster node to load its settings. This cmdlet is only valid for the local NLB cluster node and cannot be used to reload a remote NLB cluster node.
Specifies the new retain suspended setting for the cluster node.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet will ask for confirmation from the user before proceeding.
Specifies the host priority or host ID for the cluster node. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 1 through 32.
Specifies the initial host state for the cluster node. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Started, Stopped, or Suspended.
Causes the NLB driver on the current cluster node to load its settings. This cmdlet is only valid for the local NLB cluster node and cannot be used to reload a remote NLB cluster node.
Specifies the new retain suspended setting for the cluster node.
Specifies the cluster node to set.
Runs the cmdlet without prompting for confirmation. By default the cmdlet will ask for confirmation from the user before proceeding.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the host priority or host ID for the cluster node. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 1 through 32.
Specifies the initial host state for the cluster node. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Started, Stopped, or Suspended.
Specifies the cluster node to set.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Causes the NLB driver on the current cluster node to load its settings. This cmdlet is only valid for the local NLB cluster node and cannot be used to reload a remote NLB cluster node.
Specifies the new retain suspended setting for the cluster node.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode –NodeName node1 | Set-NlbClusterNode -Reload Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node1 Converging vlan-3 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example instructs the NLB driver on the node named node1 to reload all of its settings. This is required if an administrator wants to force configuration changes through the driver. This cmdlet must be run on node1 locally.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode –NodeName node1 | Set-NlbClusterNode -InitialHostState Suspended Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node1 Converging vlan-3 1

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the initial host state of the node named node1 to Suspended.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 3
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode -NodeName node1| Set-NlbClusterNode -RetainSuspended $TRUE | Format-List –Property * Cluster : newcluster Name : node1 InterfaceName : vlan-3 Host : node1.domain.com State : Converging HostPriority : 1 AdapterGuid : {99757561-22EC-44DA-B6D3-82E16B387D6C} InitialHostState : Started PersistSuspendOnReboot : True MaskSourceMac : True FilterIcmp : 0 GreDescriptorTimeout : 10

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the persist suspend on reboot setting on node named node1 to TRUE.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 4
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode –NodeName node1 | Set-NlbClusterNode -HostPriority 5 | Format-List –Property * Cluster : newcluster Name : node1 InterfaceName : vlan-3 Host : node1.domain.com State : Converging HostPriority : 5 AdapterGuid : {99757561-22EC-44DA-B6D3-82E16B387D6C} InitialHostState : Started PersistSuspendOnReboot : True MaskSourceMac : True FilterIcmp : 0 GreDescriptorTimeout : 10

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the host priority (ID) on the node named node1 to 5.

As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.

Specifies the new dedicated IP address for the cluster node.
Specifies the node of the cluster to which the dedicated IP address is set.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNodeDip –IP fe80::a585:202d:f7f6:2636 | Set-NlbClusterNodeDip -NewDip fe80::a9cb:eafb:e841:d8cf Node IPAddress SubnetMask ---- --------- ---------- node2 fe80::a9cb:eafb:e841:d8cf

The Set-NlbClusterPortRule cmdlet edits the port rules for a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. The port rule configuration you can edit includes the cluster IP address, port range, protocols, filtering mode, affinity, load weight, handling priority, and timeout.

This operation changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies a port number within the port rule to set. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule to set.
Specifies the new affinity for the cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Network, None, and Single.
Specifies the new end port for the cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the new IP address for the cluster port rule.
Specifies a new mode for the cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Disabled, Multiple hosts, and Single host.

Specifies the new timeout in minutes for the cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 240.

Specifies the new start port for the cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.

Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule to set.
Specifies the cluster port rule to set.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the new affinity for the cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Network, None, and Single.
Specifies the new end port for the cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the new IP address for the cluster port rule.
Specifies a new mode for the cluster port rule. The acceptable values for this parameter are: Disabled, Multiple hosts, and Single host.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterPortRule -Port 80 | Set-NlbClusterPortRule -NewStartPort 5 IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 5 65535 Both Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the start port of the port rule of port number 80 to 5.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterPortRule -Port 80 | Set-NlbClusterPortRule -NewProtocol Tcp IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 5 65535 Tcp Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command changes the protocol of the port rule of port number 80 to TCP.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 3
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterPortRule 80 | Set-NlbClusterPortRule -NewMode Single IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 5 65535 Tcp Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the port rule mode to Single.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the host priority of a port rule for a specific Network Load Balancing (NLB) node.

The Set-NlbClusterPortRuleNodeHandlingPriority cmdlet sets the host priority of a port rule for a specific Network Load Balancing (NLB) node. The host priority specifies a unique identifier (ID) for each node. The node with the lowest numerical priority among the current members of the cluster handles all of the network traffic on the cluster that is not covered by a port rule. You can override these priorities or provide load balancing for specific ranges of ports by specifying rules. If a new node joins the cluster and its priority conflicts with another node in the cluster, then the node is not accepted as part of the cluster. The rest of the cluster will continue to handle the traffic.

This operation changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies a port number within the port rule on which the node handling priority will be set. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the handling priority for the cluster node. This is only applicable when the filtering mode of the port rule is Single host.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule on which the handling priority will be set.
Specifies the handling priority for the cluster node. This is only applicable when the filtering mode of the port rule is Single host.
Specifies the cluster port rule on which the handling priority will be set. This is only applicable when the filtering mode for the port rule is Single host.
Specifies the handling priority for the cluster node. This is only applicable when the filtering mode of the port rule is Single host.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule on which the handling priority will be set.
Specifies the cluster port rule on which the handling priority will be set. This is only applicable when the filtering mode for the port rule is Single host.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies a port number within the port rule on which the node handling priority will be set. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode –NodeName node1 | Get-NlbClusterPortRule | Set-NlbClusterPortRuleNodeHandlingPriority -HandlingPriority 3 IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 0 65535 Both Single

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the handling priority of the given port rule for the node named node1 to 3. This is applicable for port rules with Single mode.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Set-NlbClusterPortRuleNodeHandlingPriority -HostName node1 -Interface vlan-3 -IP 255.255.255.255 -Port 80 -HandlingPriority 4 IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 0 65535 Both Single

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the handling priority of the given port rule for the node named node1 to 4. This is applicable for port rules with Single mode.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets the load weight of a port rule for a specific Network Load Balancing (NLB) node.

The Set-NlbClusterPortRuleNodeWeight cmdlet sets the load weight of a port rule for a specific Network Load Balancing (NLB) node. The load weight applies only for the Multiple hosts filtering mode. When using the Multiple hosts filtering mode, the load weight specifies the relative amount of load-balanced network traffic that this node should handle for the associated port rule. Allowed values range from 0 (zero) to 100. To prevent a host from handling any network traffic, set the load weight to 0 (zero). The actual fraction of traffic handled by each node is computed as the local load weight divided by the sum of all load weights across the cluster. Different load weights can be specified for each node in the cluster using the LoadWeight parameter. Or, all nodes can be specified to distribute the network load equally by using the Equal parameter instead of the LoadWeight parameter.

This operation changes the configuration on all cluster nodes. As a result, the NLB cluster will have to restart the convergence process on all nodes to guarantee that configuration changes have been applied on all nodes and that a consistent state is reached. Any additional operations on the NLB cluster should not be initiated until all cluster nodes have completed the convergence process and are back to the converged state.

To check the state of all cluster nodes, use the Get-NlbClusterNode cmdlet. If a configuration change results in the cluster nodes remaining in perpetual convergence, refer to the event log to resolve the configuration inconsistency between the cluster nodes.
Specifies a port number within the port rule on which the node load weight will be set. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.

Sets the port rule weight to Equal on the cluster node. This specifies that all nodes distribute the network load equally. This parameter is only applicable when the port rule filtering mode is Multiple hosts.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.

Specifies the load weight for the given port rule to use for this node. This is only applicable when the port rule filtering mode is Multiple hosts. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 100.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule on which the load weight will be set.

Sets the port rule weight to Equal on the cluster node. This specifies that all nodes distribute the network load equally. This parameter is only applicable when the port rule filtering mode is Multiple hosts.

Specifies the load weight for the given port rule to use for this node. This is only applicable when the port rule filtering mode is Multiple hosts. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 100.
Specifies the cluster port rule on which the load weight will be set. This is only applicable when the port rule filtering mode is Multiple hosts.

Sets the port rule weight to Equal on the cluster node. This specifies that all nodes distribute the network load equally. This parameter is only applicable when the port rule filtering mode is Multiple hosts.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the IP address for the cluster port rule on which the load weight will be set.
Specifies the cluster port rule on which the load weight will be set. This is only applicable when the port rule filtering mode is Multiple hosts.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.

Specifies the load weight for the given port rule to use for this node. This is only applicable when the port rule filtering mode is Multiple hosts. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 100.
Specifies a port number within the port rule on which the node load weight will be set. The acceptable values for this parameter are: 0 through 65535.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode | Get-NlbClusterPortRule | Set-NlbClusterPortRuleNodeWeight -Equal IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 0 65535 Both Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the weight for all port rules to equal the load weight on all nodes. This is applicable for port rules using the Multiple hosts. Note that this has to be set on all cluster nodes to achieve the desired effect.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode | Get-NlbClusterPortRule –Port 80 | Set-NlbClusterPortRuleNodeWeight -Equal IPAddress State Start End Protocol Mode Affinity Timeout --------- ----- ----- --- -------- ---- -------- ------- All Enabled 0 65535 Both Multiple Single 0 All Enabled 0 65535 Both Multiple Single 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the weight for the specified port rule to equal the load weight on all nodes. This is applicable for port rules using the Multiple hosts. Note that this has to be set on all cluster nodes to achieve the desired effect.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 3
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterNode -NodeName node1 | Get-NlbClusterPortRule –Port 80 | Set-NlbClusterPortRuleNodeWeight -LoadWeight 25 | Format-List * Cluster : cluster1 NodeName : node1 VirtualIPAddress : 255.255.255.255 StartPort : 0 EndPort : 65535 Affinity : Single FilteringMode : Multiple Protocol : Both EqualLoad : True LoadWeight : 25 PortState : Enabled Priority : Timeout : 0

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example sets the weight for the specified port rule on the node named node1 to 25. This is applicable for port rules using the Multiple hosts. Note that the weights have to be set on each node.

command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Get-NlbClusterVip –IP fe80::ad1c:c26a:b9d2:5679 | Set-NlbClusterVip -NewIP fe80::ae34:85b1:d7e9:d51f IPAddress SubnetMask --------- ---------- fe80::ae34:85b1:d7e9:d51f ::

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example changes the cluster virtual IP from fe80::ad1c:c26a:b9d2:5679 to fe80::ae34:85b1:d7e9:d51f.

maml:description.maml:para: Starts all nodes in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.
The Start-NlbCluster cmdlet starts all nodes in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. Once the nodes are started, NLB will include all cluster nodes in load balancing network traffic.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the cluster to start.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster to start.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Start-NlbCluster Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- cluster1 3.53.100.100 255.0.0.0 UNICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example starts all of the cluster nodes on the local cluster.

maml:description.maml:para: Starts a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster node.
The Start-NlbClusterNode cmdlet starts a node in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. Once the node is started, NLB will include that node in load balancing network traffic.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Start-NlbClusterNode –InputObject node2 Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node2 Converged vlan-3 2

maml:description.maml:para: Stops all nodes of a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Stop-NlbCluster cmdlet stops all nodes in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. The cmdlet will stop the NLB service on the host and all existing connections will be lost. To avoid interrupting active connections, use the Drain parameter which allows the host to continue servicing active connections, but disables all new traffic to that host.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Drains existing traffic before stopping the cluster. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing traffic will be dropped.
Specifies the number of minutes to wait for the drain operation before stopping the cluster. After the time expires, the existing connections will be dropped.
Drains existing traffic before stopping the cluster. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing traffic will be dropped.
Specifies the number of minutes to wait for the drain operation before stopping the cluster. After the time expires, the existing connections will be dropped.
Specifies the cluster to stop.
Drains existing traffic before stopping the cluster. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing traffic will be dropped.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster to stop.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the number of minutes to wait for the drain operation before stopping the cluster. After the time expires, the existing connections will be dropped.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Stop-NlbCluster Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- cluster1 3.53.100.100 255.0.0.0 UNICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example stops all cluster nodes on the local cluster.

maml:description.maml:para: Stops a node in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Stop-NlbClusterNode cmdlet stops a node in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. When the nodes are stopped in the cluster, client connections that are already in progress are interrupted. To avoid interrupting active connections, consider using the Drain parameter, which allows the node to continue servicing active connections but disables all new traffic to that node.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Drains existing traffic before stopping the cluster node. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing traffic will be dropped.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the number of minutes to wait for the drain operation before stopping the cluster node. After the time expires, the existing connections will be dropped.
Drains existing traffic before stopping the cluster node. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing traffic will be dropped.
Specifies the number of minutes to wait for the drain operation before stopping the cluster node. After the time expires, the existing connections will be dropped.
Specifies the cluster node to stop.
Drains existing traffic before stopping the cluster node. If this parameter is omitted, then the existing traffic will be dropped.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster node to stop.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the number of minutes to wait for the drain operation before stopping the cluster node. After the time expires, the existing connections will be dropped.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Stop-NlbClusterNode node2 Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node2 Stopped vlan-3 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example stops the cluster node named node2 on the local cluster.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 2
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Stop-NlbClusterNode -Drain -Timeout 10 Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node3 Stopped vlan-3 3

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example stops the local cluster node. Before this cmdlet stops the cluster, this cmdlet drains all existing connections for up to 10 minutes. During that time, new connections will not be established on this node. Any remaining connections after the 10 minutes will be forcefully terminated.

maml:description.maml:para: Suspends all nodes of a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Suspend-NlbCluster cmdlet suspends all nodes of a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. A cluster may need to be suspended to override any remote control cmdlets, or non-Windows PowerShell® operations, that are issued and for maintenance work.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the cluster to suspend.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster to suspend.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Suspend-NlbCluster Name IPAddress SubnetMask Mode ---- --------- ---------- ---- cluster1 3.53.100.100 255.0.0.0 UNICAST

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example suspends all cluster nodes on the local cluster.

maml:description.maml:para: Suspends a specific node in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster.

The Suspend-NlbClusterNode cmdlet suspends a specific node in a Network Load Balancing (NLB) cluster. A node in a cluster may need to be suspended to override any remote control cmdlets, or non-Windows PowerShell® operations, that are issued or for maintenance work.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.
Specifies the cluster node to suspend.
Specifies the name of the cluster host against which this cmdlet is run. If this parameter is omitted or a value of . is entered, then the local cluster is assumed.
Specifies the cluster node to suspend.
Specifies the interface to which NLB is bound. This is the interface of the cluster against which this cmdlet is run.

command:example.maml:title: EXAMPLE 1
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\>Suspend-NlbClusterNode -InputObject node2 Name State Interface HostID ---- ----- --------- ------ node2 Suspended vlan-3 2

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example suspends cluster node named node2 on the local cluster.
